Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	Having thus completed this book for you, which is the latest work on medicine with additions thereto, and having reached the end of it through his explanations and his own statements, it has seemed to me right to complete it for you with this Treatise, that is, with manual surgery.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since manual surgery is neglected in our region and entirely private in our time, until perhaps the knowledge of it has perished and its trace has been lost; and there remain from it only a few descriptions in ancient books, which have been distorted by hand, and errors and hesitations have arisen until the intentions of his art have been closed and its sight has faded: I have thought it right to revive it with the order of this Treatise according to the way of exposition, declaration, and abbreviation; and so to come to the forms of cautery tools and the rest of surgical instruments; with the addition of declarations and the elaboration of what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	Moreover, the reason why a good master of this art with his own hand is not found in our time is that the art of medicine is long; and it is necessary for its author to exercise himself in anatomy before he narrated what Galen did, until he knows the members' helps, their forms, their union and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, tendons, the number of them, and their exit, and the pulsations and quietness of veins and arteries, and the exits of places.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of this, Hippocrates said that the name is much with the name, and little with the work, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	Indeed, we have already spoken of him at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is not aware of what we have said about anatomy, will not succeed, but will fall into error, which harms men; as I have seen many among them who boast of this knowledge, yet lack understanding and experience in it.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	This is because I have seen a stupid physician cut into a scrofulous swelling on a woman's neck and he injured some arteries in her neck; therefore the woman's blood flowed until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another physician who presumptiously tried to extract a stone from a man whose urethra had become blocked due to age, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore approached him and extracted it with a urinary probe.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Why the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I had been called to extract it; and I saw from the size of the stone and the frailty of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician, who was receiving payment from a certain duke of our land for medicine. And there was a eunuch, black, who was with him; he had a fracture in his thigh near the calcaneum. The physician, through his ignorance, squeezed the fracture over the wound with lint and stitches, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he released him according to his wishes.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards, he released him after a few days and ordered him not to loosen the ligature. And he remained in that condition until his leg and foot were gangrened, and he came to his end.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	So I was called to him, and I hurried to loosen the ligature; then peace came, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption was already confirmed in the member; and I could not stop it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	So, as the corruption ceased to spread in the member, it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician, who was probing the cancerous abscess; and after a few days, it became infected until the evil of the disease increased with its owner's condition.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	This is because when the cancer is pure from a melancholy humor, then it should not be approached with iron at all unless it is in a member that can tolerate it so that the whole of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And because of that, children, it is necessary for you to know that surgery, when divided with the hand, is divided into two parts: namely, the operation associated with health, and the operation where there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already discussed at length in every section of this book where the operation lies that carries fear and trepidation.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to be careful and cautious so that you do not find foolish ways to speak and dishonor yourselves.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore, take care with caution and protection, and tend to your patients with ease and firmness, and use the better way leading to grace from God for a commendable salvation and succession; and let go of terrible afflictions difficult to heal; and free your minds from what makes you fear, so that hesitation may enter into your faith and advantage.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it remains more for your glory, and higher in this world, and finally for the extent of your power.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen indeed has already said in some of his precepts.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not treat a bad illness; do not call yourself a bad doctor.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have, however, divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	**First Chapter**
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	On cauterization with fire and acute medicine, this chapter deals with the forms and arrangement from head to foot, and the shapes of surgical instruments and cautery tools, as well as everything necessary for the procedure.
Capitulum secundum.	**Second Chapter**
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	On section and perforation, phlebotomy and venesection, and wounds: the extraction of arrows and similar foreign bodies, and all the chapter is arranged according to the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	**Third Chapter**
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, dislocation, and treatment of torsion, and similar conditions, this chapter is arranged from head to foot according to the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	**Albucasis' Surgical Textbook**
Pars I.	**Part I:**
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	On healing and damage from cauterization: what types of wounds it is suitable for, and when; and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	**Chapter I**
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before we proceed with the description of operations, it is necessary to speak of the qualities of healing and damaging factors, and in what types of wounds they manifest.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore that discourse on the quality of cauterization and its damage is lengthy and subtle, a knowledge and hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Many learned men have also spoken on this topic and disagreed; for me, however, a brief summary of their statements is sufficient, lest I prolong the discussion.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore that cautery applies universally to every type of wound that involves matter or lacks it; excepting two types of wounds, which are the hot wound without matter and the dry wound without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, there is disagreement between them regarding the hot and dry wound with matter.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some said that cautery is beneficial for those wounds.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the contrary to him, namely that cautery is not suitable for a disease arising from heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat, and it is unsuitable for healing from a hot and dry disease with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the contrary to him replied: "Cautery is a remedy for every hot and dry disease that occurs in human bodies, because when you compare the human body and its humors to the fire's complexion, you find the human body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself say by his words: for I have already tested it several times from experience.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, one should not approach it unless they have already been tested and practiced in the final chapter of cautery, and have understood the variety of human complexions, the disposition of diseases within themselves, their causes, the events that befall them, and the space of time for their duration.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	From the other complexions, there is no need for fear, especially in cold and wet diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For indeed all doctors have agreed upon these things, and they do not disagree on the use of cautery for them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, my children, that from the secret of healing by cautery with fire, and the goodness of it over cautery with medicated substances, is because fire is simple, whose action does not reach unless to the member to be cauterized, and it does not harm another member joined with it, unless in a slight way.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of medicine that fights against disease indeed reaches that which is stretched out from the body part, and perhaps causes difficulty in healing the disease in the body part, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not cause it (damage) unless it becomes excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Indeed, through experience, because of the length of service and study with art, and the focus on the truth of things, and because of that, I am excusing the length of this speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if not, because it is not permitted to this book of mine, I will present to you a hidden secret about fire, and the quality of its operation in expelling bodies, by which it expels diseases through philosophical discourse, sharpened by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, children, that they disagree in the time when it comes to making cautery, and they set a better time for the wound.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cautery is appropriate in every time: because the damage caused by chance through time is submerged in the healing brought about with cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cauterization is for necessary pains from strong, urgent pains that do not tolerate delay: because it is feared from them that a greater harm will occur than the slight damage caused by time's passing.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let not that notion fall into your minds, O sons, which they do not appreciate, except for common and stupid doctors; namely, that the illness which is healed by cauterization does not always return: and they attribute its consequences, and the matter is not as they think. For cauterization is only where medicine alters the complexion and dries up the humidities which are the causes of pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, cauterization exceeds medicine in the speed of its healing, and the strength of its operation, and the certainty of its mastery; and it is possible that the illness returns after a certain time according to the complexion of the patient, and the location of his illness, and its strength; and what is prepared in his body from the accumulation of superfluities in him. And it comes to itself in acquiring its causes from food and similar things, unless an illness occurs in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle illness in a member due to a few superfluities and humidities, such as cauterization on a tooth because of pain and similar things, is possible; for it may not return in that place the same pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that happens rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	In truth, the common opinion that cauterization is the last resort of medicine is a correct statement; not what they intend by it, for they believe there is no cure that can be achieved with medicine or any other means after the opportunity for cauterization has passed.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the contrary is true; the cautery is the last resort of medicine, not unless when we apply methods of treatment to certain illnesses and they do not help, then we apply cautery at the end, which brings about relief. Thus, what is meant by the cautery being the last resort of medicine, according to popular understanding and many physicians, is false.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	However, they said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron; and they did not say this unless because of the equality of gold and the subtlety of its substance; and they said that cautery does not cause pus in the wound.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	That is not entirely true; for I have already tested it and found that it does not work the same way in all bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cautery with gold itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you use fire cautery with gold over fire according to the amount you desire because of the redness of gold, and if it is heated too much, it melts in the fire and turns into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the artisan falls from that work and because of it, cautery with iron becomes more convenient and closer to us, as a result of its suitability for practice.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have indeed now arranged this Chapter on Wound Care, according to the chapters: and I have ordered them from head to foot, so that he who seeks anything from it may find it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	**On the Method of Cauterization for the Forehead at the Temple Joint.**
Caput II.	**Head II.**
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	**Herein is described the cauterization that rules over moisture and coldness upon the brain: these two are causes of fever, and the great flow of humors from the head to the eyes and ears, and the abundance of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain, and in general all illness arising from coldness, such as paralysis, fever, epilepsies, apoplexies, and similar illnesses.**
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	**The method of cauterization is as follows: first, you must persuade the patient: to purge the head thoroughly with a cleansing medicine three or four nights in succession, according to the condition of the patient's strength, age, and habits.**
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	**Then instruct him to make incisions on his head with a razor.**
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	**Then have him sit between your hands in such a way that he has already placed his hands on his chest.**
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your palm on the root of your nose between your eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whenever therefore your middle finger touches it, mark that place with an unhealed wound.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then use a cautery with oil: which has this form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place the same on the marked place with an unhealed wound, gradually lowering your hand, and you will turn it around.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly withdraw your hand, and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	Which if you see has now removed from the bone the amount of the skull or the amount of the zinc, then withdraw your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the same iron or another until you see the bones that I have told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then add some salt, dissolve it in water, and soak the cloth in it, then place it on the place, and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the cloth soaked in butter on top of it, and leave it over the place until the scar from the fire is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then it is treated with a four-ingredient ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They also said that the deeper and more open the wound remains, the more pus it emits; therefore, it is better and more curable.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized from the mouth to the anus; and hold the cautery until something thick from the bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it is smoothed after what is burned from the bone, then it is treated.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary to use a cautery until it leaves an impression in the bone so deep that the tooth falls out, which is done like a horn; or an instrument that women put into their vulvas when giving birth: and they think that vapors from this place are exhaled through the open wound over time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it is treated until it solidifies.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	However, these two types of cautery do not at all appear to me except in some people according to their fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to leave it alone is better for my health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head becomes weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have witnessed in the other members, and especially when the head is naturally weak and feeble, then the first species of cautery is more healthy and better for me, and I use it in my operations to preserve health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the head when it is in pain throughout the head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When a chronic pain occurs throughout the head and persists, becoming severe, it is treated with herbs, poultices, hot compresses, oils, and emollients.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with one of the cauteries we have mentioned and does not benefit from them, then consider this.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the weak head is of strong constitution by nature and is not feeble, and it suddenly feels a freezing cold, then cauterize below that point with another cautery, sparingly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize the entire head with your cautery, without letting it penetrate the skin, and expose the amount from the bone as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize the center of the head with one cautery at the place called the "vas" (a term for a blood vessel or artery), which is the place where the flow is strongest, and raise your heat upon it so that you do not expose the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	The patient indeed suffers from that constant pain, as well as various pains distinct from those of the other parts of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will say that this cauterization should be done in its place: and it is necessary that there be a cauterizing instrument for the horns of the head, and a milder cauterizing instrument for the back of his head, through which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	§ Regarding the cauterization of hemicrania, it should be done both with heated medicines and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Head IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When a painful and persistent sensation occurs in a part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and it is drained with purifying medicines for the head, and the remaining treatment is administered as I mentioned in the divisions of ailments, but it does not alleviate the entire condition, then cauterization should be done in that area according to two methods: either cauterization with heated medicine burning it, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	However, cauterization with heated medicine burning it involves taking a tooth from one person and its own skin, and cutting off the extremities of it on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then, cut the place of pain with a phlebotomist's side, until a place beneath the skin where the tooth is caught, is formed.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Therefore, introduce it into the flesh itself until it is hidden; then tighten it with a delicate constriction and leave it for fifteen hours, then loosen it and extract another, and leave the wound uncovered for two or three days; afterwards, place a cloth soaked in butter on top of it until the pus has formed; finally, treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do that with certain burning medicines, as I have written in the twelfth chapter of the book on drugs, then apply them.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Indeed, cauterization with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The burning cautery, whose form is as follows.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called the claw cautery, because its form resembles a claw, in which there is something of curvature, and in its middle there is a small eminence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot and hold your hand, and slowly turn the iron with velocity; and the amount that is cauterized should be according to the thickness of the skin, as its halfway point.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand so as not to burn the artery below, which would cause blood flow.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Next, soak the bandage in a solution of salt water and place it over the wound, leaving it for three days. Then apply butter to the bandage, and afterwards treat with ointment until healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if it be necessary, cauterize this hemicranium with the edge of a knife according to the art of cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And take care from the incision of the artery in this hemicranium, not too far or too shallow.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	§ Concerning the method of cautery in ancient hemicranium.
Caput V.	Head V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When treating a hemicranium, as we mentioned in the previous treatment and in the division of ailments, and if this treatment does not help: and you see that the illness does not suffice with the first cauterization with medicine or with cauterization with fire, then it is necessary to make the cautery with a knife until it turns white after marking on the site of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or something like that; and place your hand once with pressure, and tighten it until you cut the artery and reach the jaw.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to be cautious about the continuation of the jawbone, which moves during chewing, so that it does not burn the side or the nerve that moves it, from which spasm may occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And this should be above all a guard and caution regarding the flow of blood from an artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in cutting, there is fear, and above all to him who does not know what he is doing, and is neither studious nor expert; and he leaves the operation with that first mistake.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come to the remembrance of the regulation of the flow of blood from an artery according to its own manner and in the place of this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the severity of the wound that this cautery is not sufficient for it, and you see the body tolerating cautery in the middle of the head, as we have described, treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you see, administer cautery which we said in the chapter on extracting an artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For cauterization is indeed better and more effective with this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	# On the method of cauterizing in the case of ear pain.
Caput VI.	**Head VI.**
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When ear pain occurs due to cold, and it is cured with warm compresses, and the remaining cure as we said in division, and the pain does not go away, then apply fire cautery; and that is called 'Punctum', which has this form.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then, after the ignition of the point, it is applied around the entire ear, as it has been shown; or around both ears if pain is felt in both simultaneously.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	Then, using the cauterizing iron, stretch it from the root of the ear, shortly after you have marked the site with wax; and the amount of caustic should be ten points on each ear, approximately.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then, take care of the wounds until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	§ On the method of cauterization in surgery.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The surgery which is cured by cauterization is only of certain types that occur from phlegm, according to what we have mentioned in the division of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And for the species of cauterization that occurs from desiccation and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this species of surgery with fire, and hot irons, and gargles, and it does not confer a cure, then you should cauterize the patient three times: first at the root of the ear, second slightly below its natural position, and third at the connection of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterizing instrument from the opposite side of the weaker part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur unless it is in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the shape of cauterization is such that you cauterize the very tip of the upper ear lobe just beneath the forehead's horn, and at another time; its length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cauterizing instrument until the amount that burns through half of the skin's thickness is consumed.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the shape of the cautery, and it's a kind of knife, whose form I've described: however, it isn't too thin as you can see; and it should be that there's a little extra thickness to the knife.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with what came before; until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	# Regarding the ancient method of cauterization for apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	**Head VIII.**
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When apoplexy becomes ancient (or when, after following the aforementioned treatments and care, your condition doesn't improve and the patient does not have a fever), then cauterize them with four cauteries over all the horns of their head, and with a cautery in the middle of the head as I've said before, and another cautery at the nape of the head, according to what came before; and the manner of cauterization should be as previously described.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also cauterized with a cauterizer on the stomach's opening: and this is more ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is treated with what came before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	§ On the method of cauterization in oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the early stages of a great disease of the hip, washes that cleanse the brain be given.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then wash the entire head of the infected person, and place a plaster of cooked glue described in the treatise on plasters on their forehead, and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	The same method is cauterization itself: and it should be done according to the same order that I mentioned there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore it is cured by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then perform three cauterizations on the back part of their head, which are descending from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye, and put between each cauterization a thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for cauterization, together with what preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If, however, you wish to add to it, and the patient can endure it: then perform cauterization in the middle of it.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add it: then cauterize the very top over the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for the wound until it heals: and let cauterization be oily according to the form that has been described before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	§ Regarding the method of cauterization in paralysis and its soothing.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the purification of the head with hair, and with what we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then carefully clean the head of the patient: afterwards, cauterize the very top with hot iron in the middle of the head, and cauterize over every horn of the head, and cauterize over the back part of it, and apply three times over the spinal bones.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If, however, you need to soothe the body from many other ailments, and the patient can endure it, and the ailment is strong: then cauterize the very top with four hot irons over the spinal bones, and finish with the last iron cauterization, until much of it is burned from the skin, and draw your hand away.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for the wound itself until it is healed, and thus apply oil as a cauterizing agent.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	**On cauterization in epilepsy.**
Caput XI.	**Chapter XI.**
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic should not be cauterized except for that whose epilepsy arises from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, it is necessary for the surgeon to clean the brain first with cauterization and with the rest of the care that we have mentioned in division; when the patient's condition is severe or he is tolerant of accepting medications.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	However, if it is a child who does not tolerate medications, then gargles and brain-cleansing chews are administered for many days prior, with the aid of nutritious foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then he should shave the patient's head, after which cauterize the wound with a single cautery instrument in the middle of the head, according to what was mentioned before; and another cautery on the back of his head, and over every horn of his head with cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If the patient is strong and tolerant, then he should be cauterized with the cautery instruments that I have mentioned while having paralysis, and softening of the body over the spine of the neck and the spine of the back; and the cautery should be done with oil as before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	However, if the patient is a young boy, then apply a fine cautery in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	**On the method of cauterization in melancholy.**
Caput XII.	**Chapter XII.**
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupt humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize them with cauteries, as we mentioned regarding paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of sad thoughts and the body is weakened by moisture, then give it something to purify its brain, as mentioned before in separation; then shave the head of the weak person, and make afterwards a proper poultice from flax, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the patient, sitting square, should be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply the linen compress.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is better from an ancient sheep's tallow.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it gently over a moderate fire, to the extent that the finger can tolerate when introduced into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Next, apply a cool compress in the middle of the head in a circular motion and continue until it becomes cold.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Apply this treatment to the patient once a week, along with the rest of his regimen, until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	If it is yourself, cauterize it by making small punctures in most of it, apart from holding the hand with a cauterizing instrument; deep down, it smells bad.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This type of cauterization moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Next, place on it a cloth soaked in butter, or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	**Regarding the method of cauterization with descending water.**
Caput XIII.	**Head XIII.**
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you have determined the beginning of water in the eye by the signs I mentioned in division, then begin and wash the patient, with that which will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep it free from all moisture, and make it sit in a bath, for several days of fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command her to shave her head and burn a scar in the middle of her forehead.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then burn them deeply with two irons if there is an accumulation of water in both eyes at the same time; or from one side, if there is an accumulation of water in one eye; and cut all the veins and arteries that are under the skin, and the burns should be long in width across the temples, and cauterize to stop the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from this, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible, and I come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, cutting them off, and guarding against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is burned into the skin, under two bones, with the last two irons produced.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	**On cauterizing in ancient tears.**
Caput XIIII.	**Head XIV.**
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, continuous, and flow over the veins and arteries that are clearly visible on the outer part of the head, it is because of the excesses of cold phlegm; then burn with the same iron used at the beginning when water descends, burn in the middle of the forehead, and use two irons on each temple, and two irons on the skin under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need to add to it, then cauterize it carefully on every side with a small cautery instrument above the end of the eyebrow.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing a nose ulcer.
Caput XV.	Head XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it with what we mentioned in the previous section, and it does not respond to treatment; then apply a poultice of three nights, then shave the head and cauterize it with a medium cautery instrument and an olive cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two-sided cautery instrument above the two eyebrows slightly below the hairline.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And be careful not to injure the artery.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the clauis cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing palpebral softening.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid softens due to inflammation or moisture; then cauterize the eyelid with a single cautery instrument, this cautery should be in the shape of a crescent moon.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	If you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows with just two cauterizing instruments on every part, and they will extend from two time periods; and the length of each cautery should be according to the length of the eyebrow, and do not use your whole hand with the cautery, but rather according to the amount that is burnt off of the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this manner of lunar cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	§ Regarding the cauterization of the eyelid when the hairs turn sharp towards the eye.
Caput XVII.	Head XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery on it is according to two methods: either cautery with fire, or cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	However, in cauterization with fire, especially the sick person should be prepared beforehand to remove their hairs, if there are any that need to be cut, until they lengthen and equalize.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If, however, they are pricked near their origin: then close the patient's eyes with a bandage, so that they do not move until they heal.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have healed and equalized, then place the head of the sick person in your lap: then make signs on the eyelids of the eye with wax, marking it according to the shape of a myrtle leaf, and let the beginning of the sign be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a cloth soaked in albumen or in the mucus of psilia over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then use a hot iron whose shape is like this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the shape that you have marked gradually on many wounds until the surface of the skin is burned, which appears like the shape of a myrtle leaf entirely own.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of health of your work is: if you notice that the eyelid of the eye is contracting again and the hairs rising up near the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So raise your hand then, and leave it alone for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place a cloth with butter on it over it until the scar is gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any of the hairs return after an hour and the eyelid softens, then repeat the cauterization over that place as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	However, if the hairs are below: then cauterize it until it goes back to its natural place, and ensure that the hairs do not bother the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the method of cauterization when a burning medicine is used in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	**Chapter XVIII**
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is necessary to urge the patient to pull out the hairs until they are extended and equalized.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make a shape of a myrtle leaf from a piece of cloth.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take a known amount of soap and some dry lime, about an ounce or something like it, and rub them together vigorously while applying pressure to ensure they mix well, being careful not to let it freeze.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take the prepared piece of cloth in the shape of a myrtle leaf and place it over one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a cold compress soaked in egg white, holding the head of the patient in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your index finger on the medicine and gently press it.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it whenever the patient feels a stinging sensation from the medicine, for its sting is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While he persists in this bite that he has discovered, then abandon the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the bite has ceased, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider that if you see the eyelid lifting up as it does when it contracts with heat or a cut, it is good; but if not, then repeat the application of medicine to the place where it has left no mark or stain until your operation is complete and the eye contracted.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place a poultice of butter on it until the burnt skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with a diaphoretic ointment or any other until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you, during the operation, to take care as the last step so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If after several days the eyelid becomes soft and something from the hair falls into the eye, then repeat the medicine on that place which is becoming soft from the eyelid, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And know that the eyes of humans differ in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to that, your consideration should be such that the way of righteousness is not hidden from him who studies this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	§ On the method of cauterizing the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, as we have said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment does not bring relief, then you should cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Tell the patient to place his head in your lap and hold his head with both hands in such a way that it does not move or be agitated while he performs this act.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place the heated cloth or a piece of mucilage over his eye: then apply the cauterizing iron, which has this shape.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	It should be shaped like the curve of a reed's quill from one end, as is done with the cauterizing iron; and if it goes through to the other end or tries to go up, then it is inadequate.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this cut is better suited for your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and drain the blood from it, and clean it; and if it is not open, then open it, and drain the pus from it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place a hot iron on it, which is made to burn very much.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold it with your hand for a moment near the iron by the eye, to the side of the nose, so that your hand does not wander or disturb the patient; and place the hot iron on the fat of the eye, and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If therefore you have reached the end of your hot iron up to the mouth, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the hot iron once or twice, as you need; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then apply a cloth with butter, and treat it with an antiseptic ointment until it is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If, after forty days, it does not heal: then apply a sharp, corrosive medicine to it until the bone is exposed; and scrape it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some have called the first.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Intend to the location of the fistula and find it; then place a fine iron (i.e., a thin cannula) into that fissure.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it the quantity of a drachma of melted lead, and hold your hand firmly with good retention of the cannula, so that it does not move at all, or flow, or reach the eye with the melted lead.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you place over the eye of the patient a cloth dipped in either albumen or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Lead burns the site of the fistula and heals it with a wonderful cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	Which, when the fistula is healed through cauterization and treatment as we have said, is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if that does not happen, then it is necessary to create a nasal opening and bring the fistula back to flow with the nose, according to where it naturally goes.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	# On the Method of Cauterization in Lip Fissures.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many times, cracks occur in the lip folds, which are called pilings, especially on the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you treat these cracks, as we said regarding the division of the disease, and if treatment does not help, then use a small iron cautery in this manner.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And the depth of it should be according to the thinness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the hot iron quickly into those cracks until it reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with a poultice until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	**On cauterizing oral fistulas.**
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of a gum, or on the palate, or among the roots of teeth; it forms pus and breaks out; then it becomes gangrened and pus runs, and a fistula is formed; if treatment does not help in this case, then hot cauterization should be applied according to its size.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce the burning steel into the fistula's opening and hold your hand until the burning iron reaches its deepest point and its end: do this once or twice with two strokes.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then take care of it afterward, as we said about the treatment until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the healing separates and it heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the place and take away the corrupt bone as it comes to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	§ Regarding the method of cauterization in the gingiva and the softening of teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gingiva softens due to moisture and the teeth become loose, and treating it with medicines does not help, then put the sick head in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply the cauterizing fire, whose form comes after these steps, so that you place a tube over the tooth and quickly insert the burning cauterizing iron into it; hold your hand for a moment until the patient feels the heat of the fire reaching the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And then raise your hand; afterwards repeat the cautery several times, according to need.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then the patient should fill their mouth with salty water and hold it for one hour and then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth's motion becomes fixed, the gums, having softened, tighten and thus the corrupted moisture dries up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	§ On the method of cauterization for tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Head XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When tooth pain is due to cold, or there is actual cold within the tooth itself, or decay, and treatment with medicines does not help, then cautery should be applied in one of two ways: either cautery with butter or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cautery with butter is to take the raw butter and boil it in a copper kettle or in vessels.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a cloth, and apply it over the affected extremity.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then immerse the affected part in the boiled butter and place it eagerly over the painful tooth, holding it until it becomes numb, and repeat this several times until the strength of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	If you wish, immerse the cloth or bandage in cold butter, and place it on the aching tooth; then place a hot iron on top of it, until the fire reaches the depth of the tooth's cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	Its cauterization with fire is to aim for the air canal or the iron channel.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And it should be in the body so that the point of the fire does not reach the lower jaw.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then apply the cautery, whose shape will come together, and place it on that tooth; and hold your hand until the cautery becomes cold.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do that several times, for the pain will be moved, or on the same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary that the impression of that cautery fills the patient's mouth with good butter, and holds it for a certain time, then spits it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with any available point of the instrument according to what is possible, and this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterization for styes.
Caput XXIIII.	**Chapter XXIV**
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When styes are affected with phlegm and cold humours, and do not yield to the operation of medicines, nor permit their dissolution by heat, then apply a hot cautery of this form.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	It should have two open ends so that smoke escapes from one end as the cautery is applied to the other; then place the glowing tip on the wound once, and a second time if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the wound.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the wound is shallow, then apply the cautery according to its depth.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Afterward, leave it for three days, and apply a poultice dipped in butter on top until the charred part is removed by the heat.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with a dental ointment until the shape of the canal is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	On the method of cauterization for hoarseness and difficulty in breathing.
Caput XXV.	**Chapter XXV**
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moisture is collected over the lung channel, and especially when it is accompanied by the coldness of the skin, then it is necessary for the patient to be evacuated with the first use of laxative medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then, he should cauterize the same at the base of the throat in a depressed place, and be careful not to come across the cautery with it to the throat or skin, unless something of its own.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then, he should cauterize the same with another cautery at the joint of the neck in the last spine of it finishing: and let the cautery be made into a clasp according to the manner that preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then he should care for it with what preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	§ Regarding the method of cauterization in lung diseases and coughing.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
