Therefore, if this happens to someone, then apply with your hand directly to the opening of the artery, and place over it your index finger, and squeeze it tightly until the blood is obstructed under your finger and does not escape from it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then apply a small oil lamp and many more to the cauterization, and blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one, or a few, or a large one, according to the wound and the place where the artery is severed, and place the cauterization on the same vessel, after which you move your finger quickly; and hold the cauterization until the blood stops.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If it is expelled with the withdrawal of the finger from the opening of the artery and the extinguishing of the cauterization, then quickly take another cauterization from those prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not stop doing this with one after another until the blood stops.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn the nerves that are there, and let no further harm come to the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And you should know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to sever it; especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or when using cauterization, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or when using extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, its ends are torn, and blood is severed.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is tied with a strong ligature thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or they place over it medicinal substances that aid in stopping the flow of blood, and tighten them with a suitable constricting bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever administers the severing with ligature and tightening with cloth, or positioning of burning substances and similar methods, does not do it thoroughly unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If such a thing happens to someone and they have no doctor or medicine, then they should begin by positioning their index finger over the wound's artery opening as we described, and tightening it strongly until the blood is stopped from the upper part of the injury, and above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And let not the finger be moved, but keep it always above the cold water, until the blood becomes congealed and swollen and can be cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile, consider what it needs from cauterization or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	§ End of the First Part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Chirurgic Book of Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	§ On incision, perforation, and phlebotomy in wounds and similar conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	As we said in Chapter One, every illness that involves fire from cauterization and burning medicine, along with its circumstances, causes, instruments, and forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I have placed chapters there from the beginning to the end.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path, so that it may be clear for anyone who seeks to know about it.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary for you, O son, to learn from the fear that is in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And because of this, it is necessary to be more careful, for in the operation described in this chapter, the wound often bleeds heavily with blood, which can lead to death at the time of opening a vein, or cutting into an abscess, or opening a fistula, or treating a wound, or extracting an arrowhead, or cutting into stone, and similar things; from all these comes trembling and fear, and in many cases, death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you not to be caught off guard, for sometimes people with certain conditions come to you in this art of medicine, and they are different from others.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For some become angry when confronted with their illness, and for them, death is light because of the severity they find from their condition and the duration of their suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when illness arises from fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them are those who hand over their fate to a physician, trusting him for healing, and their illness becomes their undoing.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, you should not give in to those who come to you from among these, whose ways are such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And be more careful, than your greed and rapacity.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume over anything from that, unless after certain knowledge that confirms among you the admirable succession to which it has come.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And you should apply yourself to the care of all your sick, with prognosis and indication for what is appropriate for their healing.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In that very thing lies your aid for the sake of gaining fame, glory, memory, and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	God's Son, inspire you with his understanding, and do not deprive you of guidance and inspiration, for it is in his hands.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have indeed organized this chapter by distinguishing it into sections, following what preceded in the chapter on cauterization from head to foot: so that you may find from it whatever you seek and whatever you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	**On the treatment of water accumulated in the heads of children.**
Caput I.	**Chapter I.**
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	Know that this ailment often occurs in children at the time of birth, or when the midwife tightly squeezes the child's head without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever something happens, even due to an unseen cause that is unknown.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And indeed, I have not seen this disease in others as much as in children, and to every one of them death has followed: therefore it seemed to me necessary to give up the operation on it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And indeed, I have seen from them a child whose head was filled with water, and his head was magnified every day until he could not sit on himself because of the size of his head; and the humidity increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this humidity, either it accumulates between the skin and the bone, or it accumulates beneath the bone on the surface.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation on it, if there is humidity between the skin and the bone and an abscess is present, then you should make one crack in the middle of the head in width; and the length of the crack should be like two knots, until the humidity runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the form of the abscess.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the humidity has increased more and the abscess is larger, then put these two cracks according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the humidity is beneath the bone and its sign is that you see the openings of the commissures of the head from every side; and water sinks down when you press it with your hand towards the interior, and it does not hide itself from you, then you should make three cracks in the middle of the head according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the cut, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tighten the wounds with cloth and lint.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then sew it up from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligature, care for the wound with bandages and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not release the tension from the head equally.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the weak with dry food containing little moisture, until the member is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And there is another method of cutting as you consider where the magnitude of the abscess appears and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is in the back of the head, or on the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So rise up with the cut where you see the abscess and the collection of water, and split it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And beware not to cut the artery, and let there be no flow of blood, and the weak may die from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	On the incision of arteries that are behind the ears.
Caput II.	**Chapter II.**
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When someone suffers from a catarrh affecting the eyes or chest, and it becomes chronic and does not respond to medical treatment, then the final remedy lies in the incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when one decides to incise them, they should ensure that the diseased head is removed.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then, using a rough cloth, one should create a space so that the arteries become visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then, the diseased neck should be tightened with any cloth available.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then, consider where the pulse of the vein is located.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both [arteries] are the areas behind the depressed ears; they rarely become hidden, except in certain people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then, mark them with wax on both sides; and incise each one with a sharp scalpel on both sides accurately down to the bone; and it should be done according to the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, introduce a spatula beneath the artery and cut it towards the upper parts with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And the length of the incision should be like two joined fingers.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut, blood flows out with pulsating force, rising into the interiors with frequent jumps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	However, if the artery is not visible to the eye, then it is necessary that the distance from gold should be the quantity of space equal to three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with wax and follow until it reaches the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what needs to be released from blood is six ounces and perhaps you release more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of this according to the amount that appears to you from the condition of the patient and the fullness of the artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there remains anything near the bone from healing, cut it so that there is no risk of a hot abscess; then tighten the wound with linen bands.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with ointment until it heals.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries, which are found in certain parts of the body.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When an old headache or sudden acute catarrh occurs due to the harsh humidities and heat in the face, or because of a sharp object such as a splinter, and similar causes, and treatment with the usual medical methods does not help, then we have to resort to the extraction of arteries from these parts, or their cauterization, as we have described.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation for extracting them is to remove the weak hair from the part, and pull towards the visible artery in that time.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	It is indeed shown to you from its pulse, and it is rarely hidden unless in a few people or due to coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	If it is hidden from you, then press the weak head with any cloth you have; afterward, use fear to apply a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or use steam with hot water until it appears manifestly to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a knife that I formed a little while ago.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then use it to scrape the skin easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then insert a hook into it and pull it towards the upper parts until you extract it from the skin, and make it pass through the tunics that are under it from all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If, however, the artery is thin: then pierce it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then make an incision from that part according to the length of its ends, and tighten it, so that there is no flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not incised and not severed, the blood will not flow completely.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then take six ounces of blood from the vein until three ounces remain.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, the artery is large: then it is necessary to tie it in two places with a strong double thread, either from silk or from some other string, so that it does not flow into putrefaction before the wound heals and the blood flow occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then make an incision on the surplus, which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Perform that operation at that time, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you see it, cauterize it with a hot iron from the mouth to the end, with a cautery knife; until its ends are cut off and it becomes firm in that place through the same operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better work, unless the patient has fever or is of heated complexion.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because the cautery is from those things that dry up humors.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better drainage.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the arteries are extracted, the place must be filled with cooked fat; and small pieces of well-made cloth should be placed on top of it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the wound is dressed with dried medicines that promote the growth of flesh, and with bandages, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, while you are operating, a flow of blood from the artery occurs, then quickly proceed to cut it off with a cautery, or fill the place with a plug; and hold your hand tightly until the blood stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of those things is present to you, then place your finger on the place until the blood clots.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And it embrows the site with a steady application of cold water until the acute pain subsides and it tightens as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And because it is easier to extract arteries from a softer and more pliable part, it is done by cauterizing the vein with these two instruments, and the sharpness of both knives should be similar.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they have much less sharpness than the two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are as sharp as the two knives, both will apply coldness, and they will not cut into the flesh swiftly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Therefore, since they have a little less thickness, heat from fire is retained in them and flesh is cut swiftly; so with this, the work needs to be done better, easier, and lighter of all works.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And there should be a space between the two knives equal to the thickness of a finger, after you mark with encaustics two places; and apply fire vigorously to both until they reach the wound, and cut the vein at both places: so as to elongate what is between its extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not solidify completely with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On the treatment of continuous acute tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	**Head IV.**
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are continuous and flow from the eyes, which are situated on top of the skull, and no medical treatment brings relief, while you see the face of the patient turning red and he feels a crawling sensation on his forehead like that of ants walking, and his eyes become strained, wet, to the point that their hairs are damaged by the constant flow, and the eyelids are inflamed from the intensity of the tears, then the ancients employed a special method for treating them, calling it 'the operation with the knife'.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is as if you instruct the patient to shave the hairs on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three incisions evenly spaced along the length of the forehead, and the length of each incision should be about two fingers, with one incision placed in the middle of the forehead at the level of the nose, the second a little below the movement of the eyebrows, and the third on the other side. Be careful to avoid the arteries located on both sides. Extend your hand from the continuation of the lower jaw, and the distance between the incisions should be about three fingers. Prepare a piece of sponge or a dry cloth, with which you will absorb the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert the blade of a sharp instrument at both ends, after which comes the shape.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is from the temporal part, to the second incision: and the scar, together with it, all the skin which is between the two incisions, with the heal, which is over the mouth.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do that from the median incision to the second incision as well.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this scalpel and insert another instrument into the first incision again, which is called a sharp knife, with one side blunt, not sharp on the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side against the flesh attached to the skin, and its blunt side towards the mouth; and push it until it reaches the median fissure, and cut along with it all the tendons that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues until what appears of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do that in the median fissure until another fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when it flows from blood in an equal amount, express the places from which the coagulated blood has formed a clot.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then put in every fissure lint made from old cloth, and place over them rags soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And observe that there is no risk of a hot abscess.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day, loosen the ligature and administer a large amount of the infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then apply that care with the ointment of basilicon to the rest of the wounds, until they are healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	§ On the care of acute tears and cataracts on the eyes from internal head injuries.
Caput V.	Head V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When a person suffers from acute, intense, and persistent cataracts, you will notice their eyes are exhausted, weak, and their appearance is already debilitated; the eyelids are ulcerated, hair falls out of them, and there is a deep pain in the head, painful and causing subsequent sneezing. Then, from these circumstances, one must understand that these materials do not come out of the eyes unless through many channels.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you should advise the sick person to scrape their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one cut in that fissure in the middle of the forehead, or slightly beyond its width, and begin with the cut from the left side towards the right temple; continue the incision until it reaches the bone; then extend your hand away from the temporals, which move during chewing, until you reach the jawbone; remove all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate it between the two lips of the fissure with a hot iron or with linen lint.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tighten it from above with small threads and moisten the threads with wine and oil so that there is no risk of a hot abscess.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you dissolve it and see that the hot abscess is already approaching, then you must grind your teeth until the flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then take care of it with a drying regimen that promotes the growth of flesh, as if you were to take two parts of flour from wheat and four parts of colophony, prepare a paste from them and apply it to these wounds to promote the birth of flesh.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	§ On the care of that which falls into the gold.
Caput VI.	Head VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the gold belongs to one of four categories: either a mineral stone or something similar to stone, like iron and glass; or from a plant, such as wheat and beans; or a fluid substance, like water, vinegar, and others similar; or some kind of animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When something that resembles a stone or belongs to the stone family falls into the gold and does not add to or grow in it, expose the gold to the sun alone. If you then see the stone, distill some of the molten oil or essence into the gold.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then he should perform the extraction of the foreign body, and make the patient sneeze when ready, and press on the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you place a piece of cloth or wool around the ear area and stretch the ear towards the upper parts.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	Indeed, this treatment should be repeated many times.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	However, if it does not come out, then perform the extraction with the use of poultices, that is, subtle compresses made from pizigari (a traditional medicinal herb), whose form is as follows...
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	If therefore it comes out with the poultice, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform the extraction with a delicate, slightly curved hook.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore it still does not come out through that (method), then make a tube from metal and insert the end of the tube into the ear canal deeply, and press the material around the tube with softened wax mixed with oil, so as to block any passage except for the tube; then extract it with your strong pulling force.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	Indeed, it often comes out with what we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	If however it does not come out in that way, then take some helkalimb (a type of herbal preparation) or from a viscose (prepared glue), with which birds' feathers are caught, a small amount, and place it on the tip of a radius after you have carefully wrapped a clean cloth around it; then insert it into the ear canal easily, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If therefore it does not come out with all that we have mentioned, then proceed to divide it, before a hot apoplexy or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the manner of the incision is, as the phlebotomist makes an incision in the weakest part of the head; and he draws out blood from it according to the measure of its strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then place the weak part between your hands, and turn its ear towards the upper parts, and find a small incision at the root of the ear, near the fat, in the depressed place; and make the incision in the shape of a crescent until you reach the stone; then remove it with what is possible for you among the instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then use that incision with speed from your hourglass, and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If the matter falling into the ear is from one of the grains that grow and swell, then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	If, however, it does not obey you for its exit, then take a thin, delicate forceps in this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the cutting off of that kind from the grains that fall into the ear, and do not do that when you think that grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you place many turns on it; then remove them with hooks, or with a delicate gesture, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction to be relieved.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	When water is introduced into the ear, it is necessary for the patient to use sneezing with the initial conditioning; and he has already filled his ear with some cooked wax. And he lies over that ear where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it therefore exits through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many small stones, according to the length of your finger, thin and soft, and heat them with fire briefly, and let the patient insert one of them into his ear opening; and he should lift up from that side a little on his foot, and strike with another stone the stone that is in his ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	He should therefore continue doing that with the stone and the stone until all the water has exited.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And the water will exit in such a way that you take one from the hot water or the steam and insert its end into his ear; and light the other end with fire until it burns most of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then he should repeat the process with another cloth, and do that many times until all the water has exited; and then extract it with a tube as mentioned earlier in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	When extracting the animal that has entered it, if it is a small body, like a flea or something similar, treat it as I said regarding division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if there is a large body that appears to the senses, then perform its extraction with gestures and hooks, for it is easier than all those held in gold.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	However, when treating a spine generated in gold, if you take care of it as we said in division and distillation, and it does not respond to your treatment, then you should look at the gold in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	If something appears there from the nerves, then extract it with gestures or with delicate hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	However, if nothing appears there from the nerves, then take a tube whose form is tight below and wide above, and insert its thin end into the ear according to the amount that the patient can tolerate; then suck with it using strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do that many times until all the nerves come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	However, if they do not obey you to come out, then wrap the catheter around with wax, as I said on the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not come out with what I said, then perform distillations that the ancients are experienced in for the intersection of nerves, and you will find it in the treatise on distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your discharge be as you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, the form of which is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you can see, make this one out of silver or bronze, tightly folded below, with a small opening on the inside and a larger one on top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	It should therefore be made such that it can push what is in the cavity of the tube; and it should be made neatly out of bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a radius and insert its coated tip into the tube with proper lubrication; then pour oil or syrup or any of these medicines into the tube, and place it in the ear. Then insert the radius with the coating above, and express it gently with your hand until the oil is forced into the cavity of the ear and feels warm inside; but be careful not to allow anything cold to drip into it, for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	**On the Care of Treating an Injury to the Ear.**
Caput VII.	**Head VII.**
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes certain infants emerge from their mothers' wombs that have not been circumcised.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And indeed, it has also happened to some people that their ear tissue is damaged at birth from a wound or flesh growth within it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this operation is sometimes performed in a deep hole in the ear, which does not follow the usual method; and sometimes it happens on the outer part of the opening, and then it follows the usual method.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore, what happens in the deep ear, and which does not fit within the scope of vision, is difficult to cure in many cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in those that follow the usual method, it is necessary to place a warm compress over the ear and examine it; then, if you see the operation appearing, open it with a fine probe, whose shape follows this, with its end where there is some small width, and one part of it acute; and the rest of the probe should be smooth on both sides so as not to hurt the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the operation is caused by flesh grown in the ear canal, then hold it with a fine hook and cut it away easily until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the operation is in the deep ear, then take a thin, flexible probe and heat it slightly with fire; then insert it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If therefore you feel the operation with what the patient feels with the weight of hearing, then try to open it easily; and be careful not to wound the ear's nerves.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then place in the ear a quantity of lint according to the size of the wound you have cleaned with Egyptian ointment: do this for several days until you are free from the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take the lint, and soak it in rosewater, then sprinkle over it powdered zinc, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see that the ear has already formed a crust, then it is necessary to remove the lint and allow it with the new lint you apply in the paste made with rose oil, until the crust is warm, then take care of it until it heals completely.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If, however, there is bleeding: then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it over the ear, and use the remaining cure that stops the flow of blood as described in the treatise on distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	**On the care of the eyelids.**
Caput VIII.	**Head VIII.**
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These are the conditions that occur in the eyelids of the eye when they are sometimes moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, it is necessary to hold them with tweezers or with a hook, and cut them with a scalpel from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place a tri-cut veil over the wound.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	However, if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lens-shaped cauterizing iron.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterize them, it is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	Indeed, they often return when something remains from its roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned, and they do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	§ On the care of the eyes' grand muscles.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often it happens in the eyelids that something resembles the grand muscle in its strength and hardness, and because of that it is called Grandinus: and there is a thick aggregation of moisture in the upper eyelid and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation on them is therefore to consider at that time, if the grand muscle proceeds from it, which appears from the eyelid, and moves to every part, then its condition is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore, find the crack over it in width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then he should scrape it from all parts with ease until it is healed.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	However, if you cannot prepare to cut it off except after you have pierced the eyelid with an incision slightly, then it will harm the weak patient somehow.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If the cut is deep: then sew it up and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is minor, it will not cause you any harm from that.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	Blood will restore it and make it flesh again.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the decline is great towards the inner part of the ear away from the surface, then turn the eyelid inside out and hang the swelling with a hook; besides needing an incision, press it from all parts.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is elongated by an incision, it will not harm anything.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after cutting the swelling with mixed water and care for the place so that it becomes flesh again until the sick person is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of the axirna (eyelid) palpebrae (tissues).
Caput X.	**Chapter X.**
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	The axirna (eyelid fold) is a thickening that occurs in the upper eyelid skin. This most often happens to children, and it makes their eyes water in the morning, preventing them from seeing sunlight due to the tears, so they constantly rest their eyelids on their faces and sleep with them open, and the axirna becomes prominent and visible to the eye, and when you press on the area with your fingers, you feel the axirna between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of its operation is to place the patient's head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Next, take a linen cloth and prepare it with care, making a circle from it according to the amount that contains the axirna from all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it over the axirna and press with your fingers from all sides so that the axirna is gathered together in the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that humidity with a spatula, opening the cracks across the width, and let there not be a deeper crack than that made in phlebotomy.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	You must find the skin entirely, until you reach the axira, for indeed the axira proceeds from the fissure according to the shape of the white, swollen fragment.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Therefore, extract it with the cloth that you have inserted between your fingers towards the exterior, and turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed. Be careful not to add to the fissure, so that you can reach with the instrument to the eye, and do not injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	However, if the axira does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, add a little to the fissure with ease until the axira proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the site, and bind it with small strings.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are people who rub salt on it, and they place it into the depth of the fissure so that whatever remains from it dissolves because of that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If however, there is an abscess at the site, then take care of it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the causes of eye atrophy, that is, when the eyelid softens the eye, causing it to bulge abnormally.
Caput XI.	**Chapter XI.**
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs grow in the eyelids beyond their natural course beneath the skin, and they become old, they harm the eye and cause various diseases, such as frequent tears, eyelid softening, and clouding of vision, until that becomes the cause of eye destruction.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And eye atrophy is treated according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as mentioned in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or eye atrophy is treated by cutting and stitching.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by tubes, as I will mention.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You must place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns out well, so much the better.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not, insert a needle into it, where the thread is located at the lower part of the eyelid, and make it penetrate upwards with the thread, so that it comes close to the individual hairs themselves, that is, close to the margin of the eyelid, where the hairs are born; then pull the thread towards the upper parts with the eyelid, and turn it with the radius.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then, find the inner part of the eyelid, beneath the added hairs, with a spatula-like instrument, from the larger tear gland to the smaller one.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread and place a small piece of cotton or cloth beneath the eyelid; then mark on the eyelids with wax, which should be like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that the shape be made according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid, since it differs in humans.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	Indeed, there are those who need to have the eyelid incised with a large quantity, according to the amount that becomes soft from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then, with the spatula, find the two lines you marked and begin from the larger tear gland to the smaller one, and let there be a single fissure near the natural hairs, according to the thickness of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Next, introduce a hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then, scrape off the entire skin from that area.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then, sew together the two edges with a needle and fine thread, to stop the bleeding and allow the excess threads to adhere above the two eyebrows, for some things may puncture if you do that; and if not, take no concern.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then, leave the suture and thread until three or four days; after that, take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without stitching and care for it so that it dries and contracts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is lifted at the sealing of the wound and its aggregation, but it will improve in time.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	The ancients taught this method of healing.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is a concern about the patient's condition, and it comes from good practice, and there is no fear in that.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And there is another method in Ataxmir as well; it is like signs on the eyelids in the form of a figure that resembles a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then elevate the eyelids with three hooks separated or joined, according to this form which follows, and then cut off the excess with small scissors, according to this form, with equality in the incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	However, if it is not possible for you to hold the hook or if it does not align, then take a sharp instrument with which there is a thread, and insert it into the middle of the figure, and insert another thread near the larger tear, and a second thread near the smaller tear, and join the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then elevate your hand equally, and raise the skin above which the mark is made, as we have described.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then join the two lips of the wound with stitching, and take care of it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If indeed there is an abscess near your incision or fracture, fill it with gauze and similar materials, using healing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelids also turn, as if their hairs are converting.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, it is necessary to use what we have said about the wound: but the stitching of each (side) is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	**Concerning the care of the eye with dogs.**
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And thus, as you turn the eyelids and cut the gap that is inside, according to what I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then, with the artifice, make two tubes or two thin pieces of wood: whose length should be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than the width of the space: and you have already cut at both ends on each side where you hold the thread.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then, join each with delicate threads over the excess of the eyelid and tighten the two tubes on both sides with a strong twist, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin, when tightened, will die, and turn black, and rot until it falls off on its own.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If, however, it is delayed, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When it is healed, raise the eyelid; and the hairs will no longer hurt.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of the two tubes that you will make according to this shape and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	On the elevation of sharp pilons in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	**Chapter XII**
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation consists of taking a thin needle and introducing it into the eye with a delicate, flexible thread.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its ends together and tie each one with a very thin knot; the length of the threads should be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then take another thin thread and compose it beneath the first in a small knot, and tie the ends of it if visible.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then the patient should lay his head in your lap, close to the light, so that the operation may be shown, for it is a delicate and minute operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with the thread into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you extract it above the natural pilus.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the hair up to above the thread and introduce the hair into the thread; if it is one, or two, or three, and not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the hair comes out of the eyelid together with the thread and natural pilus.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If, however, the thread is withdrawn from the wound without the hair coming out with it: draw the hair to the lower part, using the thread which you have woven into it, until the hair emerges from the upper opening, and you see it with your eye; then draw both the hair and the thread, and close the eye, and leave it closed for two or three days, until the hair adheres to its place and grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either associate a longer thread with it from its natural hairs, and it will be lifted along with it; or leave it until it lengthens after some space, and then lift it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	§ On the care of the alxatrati (lidding) which occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this alxatrati (lidding) occurs in the eye, it is called leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this alxatrati (lidding) is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	The accidental alxatrati is caused by the healing of a wound, or its cutting or burning, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of treatment is that you should find that healing, and separate the lips, and place something between them, a kind of gap from linen, and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary to use in the treatment of this things that burn and contract, for if you do so, it will return to Alxatrati (Albucasis) in a worse condition than before; rather, use things that soften, such as fenugreek; mix with water in which cooked aloe is soaked, or linseed oil; and apply it with a poultice or use it for treatment.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And the treasure of your treatment is to preserve every intellect so that it does not harden according to its original form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this very operation that we have mentioned is nothing but a correction of Albucasis, so that it does not return to the original form of the place at all.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	§ On the treatment of Albucasis (for) the lower eyelid, which is a swelling or contraction upward towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XIV
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This treatment of Albucasis (for) what occurs below is what is truly called Albucasis.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is both natural and accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And accidental injuries occur from wounds, cracks, burning, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the way of operating is to take hold of a sharp instrument, where there is a double thread, and insert it into the flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal to the right lacrimal, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh towards the upper parts with the knife, and cut it with a broad scalpel.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If it then returns to the shape of the eyelid as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if it does not, take a radium (a pointed instrument) and insert it into the fissure, and turn the eyelid with it. Find two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of these fissures meet at the two angles of the incision, until they form an angle. Until this is achieved, when they are joined, the shape of these will be like a Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh along the length of its sharp lower side, from where it follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts, using a thread of linen.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with the medicines that we have mentioned, and bandages, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if an injury to the eyelid occurs from a fracture, and stitching or cauterization is required, then it is necessary to find the flat surface of the fracture beneath the eyelash, even as it was previously.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two eyelids with a sharp instrument, as we said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And in summary, regarding the care of the eyelid, whether it is above or below, the treatment should proceed as prepared according to Albucasis's form.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	Indeed, it (the treatment) varies greatly in form: the skilled artisan prepares the tool in any way possible until they restore the figure to a natural or nearly natural form, and the patient themselves, as appropriate from the operation and instruments in many arrangements.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	§ On the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	This hardening occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid hardens with the whiteness of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore, it is necessary that you insert the tip of the instrument beneath the eyelid and lift it upwards, or extend it with a hook, then cut the adhesion with a fine spatula, which should not be sharp but slightly blunt, so as not to disturb the patient during the operation, and remove the spatula, and harm the eye with its sharpness, and make the incision such that it frees that adhesion easily until, when the eyelid returns to its natural form, the whole adhesion is healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then apply a salt water wash to the eye, and rinse it with water; or let it drip onto the eye from a sieve made of silk, dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Next, separate the eyelid and eye with a lint-free linen; place a compress soaked in albutylin on the eye, and use a sieve and compresses, strengthening them daily, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	§ On the cutting of the fingernail and the prominence of the flesh of the tears.
Caput XVI.	Head XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the fingernail is of two types.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	It is either nerve-like, similar to hard, yet delicate silk.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nerve-like, similar to the white frozen moisture; which when touched by hot iron or attempts to grasp it with a hook, it separates and does not adhere to the hook.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And neither of these types begins, unless from the tear gland, gradually increasing until it obstructs vision and blocks light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of cutting it is: place the weak head in your palm.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then he opens his eyes and lifts his eyelids with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather a finger with a hook having made it slightly thin, and extend it towards the upper part.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take some thread and insert a needle into it from the equine hair, or wool, or silk; make sure the thread is strong, and bend both ends of the needle slightly, then fix it in the middle of the finger: and pierce through with the needle, and tie the thread to the finger, and extend it towards the upper part: and scrape along the side of the finger nail that follows the pupil, as if you were grasping it with the thread until its very end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.
